content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nicely done, clear description - difficulty level matches.
Nicely done. I've never heard of Lychrel numbers, so thanks.

[Goal: Lychrel Background and Rules]

- The reverse-and-add process already states that numbers have to be operated on (reversed and added) in its original base. Consider removing the corresponding rule.

- Consider specifying in step 3 of the reverse-and-add process that leading zeros of the resultant number should be discarded. You can then remove the corresponding rule.

- I would condense the description of Lychrel numbers to: "Applying the reverse-and-add process repeatedly to most numbers eventually results in palindromic output. But some numbers, expressed in some bases, do not produce any palindromic output after {{1000}} iterations. For this puzzle, these numbers will be called Lychrel numbers." You can add on more details of Lychrel numbers or even further reading (e.g., https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lychrel_number) at the end of the description.

[Goal: Task]

- Numbers are written using digits *0*-9 and letters A-Z. Here, I would recommend moving this to the Input description instead. Your task can simply be stated as "Given a number [[number]] of base [[base]], your task is to determine ...".

- Consider specifying that at least one iteration has to be performed: "... your task is to determine the first palindromic number obtained by applying the reverse-and-add process <<at least once>> (even if the original number is palindromic)." You can then remove the corresponding rule.

[Constraints]

- Please specify that range of original numbers in the constraints section. E.g.: 1 < [[number]] (in base 10) < 10^140.

- Consider specifying an upper bound on the number of characters expected in the output. E.g.: length of output < 250.

- Please add a constraint where the original number contains no leading zeros.

Title
* Consider removing the question mark from the title.

Goal
* Please remove "(2 â‰¤ base â‰¤ 36)", as it's already stated in the Constraints section.

* Please correct these typos:
  â€¢Â 1â€“9 => 0â€“9
  â€¢ ne number => the number
  â€¢ palyndromic => palindromic

* Consider removing the rule "Leading zeros must be ignored when reversing a number." The rule doesn't appear to affect the outcome of the process and may be unnecessary.

Output
* Please add "first" after "obtain the".

* Please correct the typo: aplindrome => palindrome.

* Please format "Candidate Lychrel" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* Please add these constraints:

[[number]] is a positive integer and contains at most 200 digits.
[[number]] contains only valid digits for the given [[base]] and has no leading zeros.

Cases
* Please remove the trailing newlines from the input of the cases below:
  â€¢ Validator 11
  â€¢ Can't do more ! (Test 12)

* Please remove the trailing newline from the output of the case below:
  â€¢ Y Base 36 (Test 2)

* Please modify Validator 12 so that the starting number contains more than 100 digits, similar to Can't do more ! (Test 12).

* The base is 10 in 7 out of 12 pairs of cases. Please add a new pair of cases where:

  â€¢ the base is not used in any existing cases,
  â€¢ the starting number is a palindrome,
  â€¢ and if possible, the starting number has more than 100 digits and requires more than 99 iterations to reach a palindrome. If this isn't possible, please use the largest feasible number of digits and iterations.

Cover picture
* Consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

Thank you very much for the kind review of my work. I think that all your suggestions have been considered in the new version. 
It's a bit hard to provide "extreme" case in other basis as there are very few results in the litterature for basis different from 10. However, I added some cases for palindromic original numbers in different bases. And there are now the two most delayed palindromic numbers known so far investigated into the last Test/Validator pair.
Some of the points have been addressed in a different way.
Thank you for approving the contribution and for your kind feedbacks!
Thank you very much for your review. All your suggestions have now been considered in the new version.

Thank you. Could you please follow up the points below?

Goal
* Please remove the following text, as it simply repeats the paragraph above the heading:

"Lychrel Numbers
Applying the reverse-and-add process repeatedly to most numbers eventually results in palindromic output."

* Please change "any palindromic output" to "a palindromic number".

* Please change "readings" to "reading".

* Please remove the space before the colon in the second example.

Output
* Please remove ", leading zeros removed", as additions shouldn't produce leading zeros.

Cases
* We already have a lot of base-10 cases, so it'd be preferable not to add more ðŸ˜‰. I used your code to randomly generate the following cases. Please add them to the puzzle:

Input
35
51730S0T3UR5ESRTNMLMOHC
Output
45
9YYA9EOYWQA2VVQTJKUWWUKJTQVV2AQWYOE9AYY9

Input
24
6NH6BHCBMJ8JKEFGDEKLN3L4
Output
42
16EFGHFMNBFDCH7366II6637HCDFBNMFHGFE61

Thanks again.
Thank you for your relevant comments. They all have been accouted in the new version.
Could you please move the new cases to between Pair 11 and Pair 12? They should appear before the "long" cases. Thanks.
Now all the tests appear in the right order. Thank you for the remark!
